title: Ticket #4089: errno trashed by threading code for some IO operations
description: Blocking I/O operations in condor_read(), condor_write(), and Selector are surrounded by thread calls that allow other threads to run while the I/O blocks. After the operation completes, errno (or WSAGetLastError() on win32) is checked on failure. However, stop_thread_safe() makes calls that can overwrite that error code. The callers need to save errno/WSAGetLastError() before calling stop_thread_safe().
remarks:
2013-Nov-22 13:16:20 by tannenba:
Are you sure this code is needed?

My aging memory seems to recall that on with glibc, when using pthreads, errno is stored in thread local storage automagically. And on Windows, WSAGetLastError info is also stored in thread local storage iirc.

I guess I never knew anything about MacOS...

2013-Nov-22 13:24:45 by tannenba:
Oh, maybe you are saying that system calls inside of stop_thread_safe() can trash the errno sitting in TLS?

Maybe it would be better to protect errno inside of stop_thread_safe()...

2013-Dec-06 13:35:25 by jfrey:
I don't think it matters much whether errno is saved inside or outside of stop_thread_safe(). I did it outside because in the future, there could be callers that don't care about errno.

2013-Dec-09 15:10:25 by gthain:
CODE REVIEW Approved.
check_ins: 2013-Nov-20 15:39   Check-in [38779]: error trashed by threading code for some IO operations. #4089 Save errno (or WSAGetLastError() on win32) before calls to stop_thread_safe() if we're interested in the value. stop_thread_safe() makes calls (like dprintf()) that may overwrite the error value. (By Jaime Frey )
